I don't generally recommend things in a public place, because it seems a little pointless, but I hope this helps someone make a decision.

I've played every 2D Metroid, I've dabbled in more recent Castlevanias, I've done a lot of platformers. ESA managed to hold my attention for over 75 hours of exploration, trying somewhat challenging things, and more exploration. This is Hempuli's first commercial release to my knowledge, but he spent about 3 years tinkering with this game and trying to make it better. This is a better-designed metroidvania than Super Metroid was. There's no arbitrarily huge amount of health that you need to recover by grinding off of little enemies spawning out of pipes. You find a save, you get your health back, you fan out in multiple directions and see if you can find anything. The only real negative I can think of when it comes to ESA's exploration is that you don't find some little missile pack buried in each room, stuffed in a wall. You don't get that momentary gratification and pointless increase to the capacity of a weapon you'll never use. Instead, when you find some health or a bonus item, you feel massively more rewarded. That's not for everyone, but it's certainly for me.

reviewText:
ESA is a game. It is a game about a space station. You as the protagonist is tasked in figuring out what has happened to it and its survivors. And that's about it for the story. Quite honestly, the fact that things are like that is fine for me. Although it does seem a bit same-y in terms of the sci-fi genre, the story is placed well not only with the various logs and computer terminals that are scattered about, but the environment and the atmosphere that each unique area presents.

The gameplay is good, and the item progression solid. It feels similar in pacing to Metroid Fusion, but it doesn't handhold you, nor are there long lengths of dialogue or exposition (okay, maybe it's more similar to Zero Mission). Enemies are distinguishable and have their own behaviours. All the bosses have their own strategies so you can't simply tank damage, and each battle a challenge to defeat. Each upgrade you get feels worthwhile and rewarding.

The sound effects of this game are great. From the various bits and pieces of the station that are still running, the pitter patter of water in the caves, to the heated areas that is the Volcanic Sector--all of it combined with the soundtrack brings its own feel. The soundtrack is closer to the 16-bit era of music instead of the blippy chiptune noises you get from the current nostalgia-hype of 8-bit music, and it's refreshing to hear it.

There's plenty of secrets to be had even if you finish the game. It doesn't pull the move of locking you into a predefined end-game path; the world remains quite open for you to explore. Health upgrades are pretty important items to find as later bosses take more hits to kill and find more ways to damage you, but that's not the only secret hidden on this station. I thought I'd seen everything, but then another one popped up.

It might be a while before I truly can consider myself 100%ing the game, but I can say that this game is great, and I recommend that you buy it. Watch out if you think ESA is going to be easy. It's not.

One particular boss appears after you activate something that causes new mobs to appear throughout the whole game. I finally beat him with 5 hp and promptly got killed on the next screen by the new mobs (that I didn't know were there now.)

This is bad. LET ME SAVE after killing a boss. Having to repeat a boss is incredibly frustrating, but I repeated it and moved on.

And on the flip side, don't make me have to go through 3-4 screens of tricky jumps and a tough mob fight to get to a boss with no opportunity to save. This is what finally did me in on the next boss. I will not be finishing the game because I don't have the patience to keep repeating this.

With over 500 games on Steam and another 200 on my shelves dating back to the '80s, I'm not what you'd call a newb. This game kicked my ♥♥♥.

But, it was still a lot of fun while it lasted, and if you are a hardcore player or they eventually add an easy mode, it's well worth the money. Even if you don't finish it, there's a lot of fun here for $8.

Edit: I couldn't let it kick my ♥♥♥. I did go back and finish it. Everything I said above still applies. The main problem is pre and post boss fights, and they should add an easy mode for more casual players. Everything else is top-notch.

Story time. So I was looking at the Axiom Verge reviews right when that came out and saw someone bring up this game as a better version of what Axiom Verge was trying to do. I don't know how Axiom Verge is, I still haven't played it, but I do highly doubt it'll be able to absolutely blow me away like this game did.

The controls are tight and the movement abilities are great and useful. You're given a lot of power and even still the game remains consistently challenging from beginning to end. Unless you break it with one of the last two powerups, that is.
...though, even then the game can still find ways to challenge you.
The game map is pretty decently sized and very dense, making it quite fun to explore and find all the hidden nooks and crannies, secrets and powerups. There's a lot of variety too, I don't really recall any rooms that felt wasted or pointless, each brings something new to the game. The bosses, too, are pretty diverse, basically every type of boss you can imagine is here and there are no repeat bosses at all. And some of them are damn hard, the hardest parts of the game for sure.
But? The difficulty is always fair. Never did the game present me with a challenge that seemed completely unreasonable. Every boss can be defeated without taking a single point of damage if you learn their patterns and how to dodge their attacks while still taking them down quickly. No secret is so obscurely hidden that you wouldn't possibly be able to figure it out. It's all fair, just challenging. It makes you think outside of the box to progress or find all there is to find, but everything makes sense.
There's a lot of content, too. Simply playing the game to completion should run you 8-10 hours if you're exploring around and looking for secrets along the way, and completing the postgame can easily run you another 5-8 depending on how good you are at puzzle solving. And boy, the postgame puzzles. Very reminiscent of La-Mulana in the way the main game is reminiscent of Metroid, but much less cryptic without making things too obvious. I hope you were paying attention to the station's layout and rooms while playing through if you want to complete the game, though.
I'm just. Utterly in love with this game, it's probably my favorite traditional metroidvania out of all the ones I've played. Very fun experience and the price is really, really low for how much the game has going for it.

reviewText:
Environmental Station Alpha (ESA) is a challenging Metroid-like that focuses on exploration and interesting platforming mechanics. You play as a robot who has just discovered an abandoned station somewhere in outer space. You'll explore to unravel the mystery of the dissapearance of the station's crew, and the strange things going on in the local computer system.

Pros:
- excellent movement & controls
- unique upgrades add to interesting platforming
- great soundtrack; atmospheric and fits the retro theme
- optional upgrades & rewards for further exploration
- Checkpoints/warps/shortcuts to areas keep the game interesting up until the final stages of the game so things don't get too repetitive.
- The most hardcore challenges of the game are often optional, however, a completionist is going to have intense difficulties to overcome in the end-game.

Cons:
- Some bosses are annoying if they're too challenging. The jog back to the bossroom is often short, but any time I have to face a boss more than 10 times just to get lucky can get old (I know, I know, git gud... ;)
- No Steam achievements
- *edit: i had a complaint about the ending, but continued playing and realized I hadn't actually finished the game :P

Similar to other classic action/puzzle games, in ESA the player finds upgrades and power-ups throughout the world (Charge Shot, Dash, Energy Upgrade, etc.) and uses these new tools to gain access to new areas. Don't think this is just a clone, however, because ESA adds a number of unique upgrades that become integral to your movement and survival throughout the game.

Developments in the storyline will tell the player their next objective on the map, but ambitious players will be rewarded (sometimes with with killer, optional upgrades) for further exploration into the many different routes and rooms hidden throughout the world. The developer also did a great job with keeping things interesting while backtracking through previously explored areas - new enemies and traps emerge to prevent you from taking the easy path back to an objective.

I don't want to spoil too much in this review, but suffice to say that when I beat the game I did not get the best ending possible. It looks like there is still A LOT for me to explore in this very involved and complicated map. It's clear to me now that the developer just might be a sadist and has likely lured many a gamer into obsession with this completionist nightmare. And yet we must be stalwart and overcome the challenges presented us.

For a game that borrows so heavily from one of the greatest and most influential series in gaming history, ESA is a shining example of a great idea made better with creative innovation.

reviewText:
It's good.  It's real good.  I am still enjoying the game thoroughly, even though I beat it hours ago.  It's one of those games that sucks you in while you're playing it, and stays on your mind when you're not.  The controls, graphics, atmosphere, and music all come together into a nice polished enjoyable experience.

I'll get the flaws out of the way first.  I really only see two, and they are quite minor:

Pacing - If it's your second or third time through, the game probably plays fairly smoothly start to finish.  However, on the first try you will likely spend a fair bit of time searching for the next powerup, switch, or boss that advances the game.  I ended up revisiting the same dead ends a couple times, and this was occasionally frustrating.

'One-way Loops' - The map is a necessity to the game.  However, often times when looking at the map it appears there may be two similar paths from your current location to the place you want to go, but only one of them is passable in the direction you are traveling.  It's sometimes very frustrating to almost get to your destination only to find out that “you can't get there from here”.  More than once the only way there is not the obvious way.

These are very minor gripes.  Minor, because of the nature of the game's strong points, like:

Exploration! - The game is large, and so much more full of variety than you could have possibly expected out of an 8x8 tile set and an “imaginary sound chip”.  There's so much to see and discover, and it all looks fantastic in its low-fi splendor.  Every portion of the station has it's own look and atmosphere, it's own enemies, and it's own set of unique and interesting challenges.  So when you're not sure where to go next, just go somewhere.  It's nice there.

Controls - The controls are tight.  They have enough predictability so that getting through a difficult area is much more a matter of practice than it is luck.  More than once I encountered a room or a boss where my first reaction was, “You've got to be kidding me, this looks impossible.”  However, after a few attempts (yes, you'll be retrying things regularly), the precision and repeatability of the controls becomes evident, and the completion of said room or boss is a very rewarding payoff.  Several times I found myself saying, “Wow!  I really pulled that off!  I'm amazing!”  Which brings me to:

Rewards - Accomplishing a difficult series of jumps, finding that one secret spot that looks a little different than the others, and beating that punishing boss are usually good enough rewards in and of themselves.  However, occasionally you'll find an optional powerup that is just a joy to use.  You know what I'm talking about, because you've played other Metroidvania-type games.  It's that powerup that lets you go back through other areas that were difficult the first time, and completely tear them up.  Blasting through them so much faster than before while wearing a big stupid grin and giggling a little.  Yes, this game rewards its players for a job done well.

Hints - Not really the obvious hints that tell you where to go next, but rather subtle hints like difficulty that say, “Maybe you should turn back.  This will be easier later.”  Usually if you encounter an area or enemy that seems unfair, it probably means you're headed in the wrong direction.  HOWEVER.  Several times throughout the game I stuck with it and muscled through an area ahead of schedule.  Not necessarily breaking the order of the game, but possibly to get a health or weapon upgrade a little early, so that I could have a little breathing room in the challenges ahead.  Very rarely was there ever an “all that work for nothing” situation.

Atmosphere - The graphics, animation, and music put you there in the game.  Occasionally you'll spot inspiration from other beloved games in the genre, but it all really stands on its own, even if you're not bringing all that rosy nostalgia with you.  The water area is calming yet dangerous.  The lava area is close and oppressive.  The jungle area is verdant and lush.  At every point along the journey, the game draws you in to its amazing atmosphere.

Free DLC - Yep.  The game received an update recently which included an optional new (seemingly large) area with new music, enemies, and graphics.  It's clear this developer enjoys their work.

Like I said, I beat it, but I'm definitely not done with it.  I'm not a completionist by any means, but the game still has so many interesting things to do that it will be keeping me entertained for a good number of gaming sessions yet.  If you've ever enjoyed a Metroidvania game, this is definitely one to add to your library, and it seems almost criminal to be buying it for under ten bucks.

P.S. My biggest request is for a Linux port.  Streaming it to a Linux machine has a number of issues that other games do not, and it has some deal-breaking control issues when played under Wine.  So if you want to play it on your Linux machine, you're fairly well out of luck unless you're better at troubleshooting strange issues than I am.  Since the game is built on MMF2, a Linux port (while not directly supported by MMF2) should be possible and mostly hassle free through a 3rd party library.  I think this developer has a bright future, and hopefully a Linux port can put a few extra dollars in their pockets, and help speed them along through their next project.

reviewText:
Environmental Station Alpha is hands-down my favorite metroid-like/exploration based platfromer game ever made and just one of my favorite games in general - 3rd to be specific.




Now that i have your attention, let's start the review.



The Story:

The story of ESA is simple, but effective. I revolves around the titular Environmental Station Alpha and the mysterious events that caused it to be abandoned many years ago. You, a robot of one of the many other stations, are tasked to find out what happened here. As you progress you'll find bits and pieces of the incredibly depressing, detailed and devastating story behind the station's destruction. Most of the story is told through these optional world- and story-building tools called diskette readers, which are found all over the station and consist mostly of the desperate and confused ramblings of trapped researchers who are on the verge of death. The story- and world building in this game is even better done than in Metroid Prime, as the story is seemingly told OUT OF ORDER, which means you have to piece the puzzle together, and if you decide to complete this game, it will be one  hell  of a puzzle. Another way this improves on the Prime formula is by having them also subtly tell you where to go next to progress the story, whereas in Prime it's conveyed through text prompts that pop up randomly on your visor. the difference is in ESA it's optional and more sublte.


The Setting:

The setting in this game is without a doubt my favorite setting in video game history. It does just about everything right. The Environmental Station Alpha is as previously explained, an abandoned space station revolving around artificially created biomes where expirements were held. This premise already guarantess immense variety, and Esα delivers on that promise. The station is a blend of industrial and organic, which makes it more fun to explore. But that's not a new idea, what is new is the way the narrative plays with the setting and vice-versa. Think of the Esα as the B.S.S. research station from Metroid Fusion if it was abandoned after it had been destroyed for years instead of just a short period of time. You are exploring the aftermath of 3 disasters that striked at once. The cave complexes have collapsed, the jungle has overgrown and the ocean sector has collpased into multiple areas of the station, flooding into the other sectors. There are 3 areas that are even more notable, but you'll have to see for yourself. It's hard to describe what makes the world of Esα so immersive, but the music definitely plays a part. The soundtrack is has some of the best ambient pieces i've ever heard. I've never felt this lonely yet this mesmerized and eager to explore an area in a video game. There is so much to say about the setting i could fill 10 reviews with it, but i'll let you see. The graphics, the colors, the narrative, the music, the gameplay, the sound design, it ALL feeds into the setting perfectly and vice-versa.

The Gameplay:

Esα introduces a few new elements that improve on the 2d metroid formula while simplifying it a bit too. The first notable difference: you DON'T HAVE A PROJECTILE, and never obtain one too. This is HUGE. This means that the combat is handled diffrently, and in my opinion, handled better. You have to approach and take advantage of your movement options a lot more which makes for a more dynamic game. There are upgrades, some optional and some mandatory that make it easier. In terms of movement, you get 2 airdashes - 1 horizontal and 1 vertical - that you can use once in the air unless you obtain a hard to find end-game item that allows you to dash infinitely. An then you have the hookshot, which is the grappling beam from super metroid except more fluid, more dynamic and can grapply to 99% of the ceiling in the game. But the biggest change in movement is weirdly enough the height of the character? The robot you play as is proportional to every block in the game, so say goodbye to the slightly clunky morph-ball mechanic and say hello to seamless exploration. All of these movement options and the way the combat is handled make the already great bosses even more fun to fight. The way the power-ups are distribued is also genius. Instead of handing out powerups like fast food companies hand out diabetes this game only has 14 power-ups, 4 of which are optional. This means that every time you upgrade your character it feels like a geniune accomplishment instead of a small bonus. One last thing to add is the amount of health. Your health caps out at 30, meaning no metroid 1600-health-that-depletes-surprisingly-fast ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t and more perfect difficulty. It's Super Metroid without any of the bad stuff. (btw if anyone thinks i hate the 2d Metroids i don't, i just think they have flaws that Esα improves on)


The Rest:

There is so much more to talk about, the insane post-game, I could go wayyyy more in-depth about the story, setting and gameplay, but i'd rather you find out yourself. Hell, I haven't even done everything in this game! I haven't even beaten the best boss in the game! Another note is: if you don't have the correct graphic card or an average PC not suited for gaming like me, expect this game to be buggy. But even with that, I had one of the best experiences i've ever had in my life playing this game. A character-limited review system like steam's can not do this masterpiece justice.



I'm feeling a strong to STRONGER 10 on this game.

I'm six hours into the game, so I think I have a fair grasp on the game to write a review. First thing's first, if you're a fan of unfair games, this is the sort of game you might want to pick up. That's not to say it's unbeatable, just have fun re-loading because you took one hit in the gauntlet before the boss chamber.

Pros: Graphics, sound, and gameplay are all good. The graphics are low-bit, but done in a style that works. Music is just phenomenal. The gameplay is pretty fluid and easy to get the hang of. The atmosphere is done absolutely wonderfully.

Cons: There really aren't any outside of my personal gripes, to follow. It runs smoothly and if the extreme unfairness is your cup of tea, then all the power to you.

Gripes: The game is unfair and difficult. The hard spots are hard enough, but you find yourself taking a lot of cheap shots in a lot of places. Unfortunately, taking a hit or two on the way to a boss means you either have to have the boss down pat and not be off by a microsecond with any of your moves, or just re-load. Health is far too scarce for it's own good, and when you do happen across an upgrade, it's usually completely inacessable until much later in the game. There are exceptions of course, though the game pretty much just taunts you with health that you desperately need, especially on later bosses. There are no health pickups whatsoever, and what little they did to assuage that quickly becomes inadequate. You need to just get used to the controls and avoid taking hits rather than actually staying and fighting. Especially when everything you encounter starts to hit you for more than one point of damage, because even at max, normal mode's HP cap is 30. You wind up being incredibly flimsy. Oddly, I found the difficulty varies rather harshly from one boss to the next, one boss will beat you over and over and the next one you'll beat on your first or second try.

At the end of the day, I have to say that these games are the most fun when your effort is actually rewarded, and your efforts are usually rewarded with obstacles you can't pass.... yet. Kinda takes the wind out of exploration. I found myself tentative about even exploring, since if it wasn't the right way to go, there would be no payoff. And that's just no fun. And now to actually beat this game...

reviewText:
Although I had never heard of Environmental Station Alpha prior to it showing up on a friend's activity feed, I went ahead and bought it on a whim, only to enjoy it more than any other game I played in 2015.

The game is inspired by Super Metroid to the point of saturation, but still manages to stand as a brilliant game in its own right, with tight controls, outstanding boss battles and an excellent soundtrack. Many reviews both positive and negative will touch on the difficulty of the bosses, but each of them behave consistently enough that victory is not a matter of luck, but figuring out the correct counter-strategy and perfecting its execution. Enduring defeat long enough to establish this muscle memory admittedly requires equal parts humility and stubbornness. However, the sense of accomplishment that follows defeating each boss easily justifies each failed attempt.

Beyond the excellent boss fights, the game's greatest achievement is the fact that exploring the station is not only fun from the very beginning, but becomes even more enjoyable as the game continues. The various power-ups obtained over the course of the game -- and I strongly recommend tracking down the optional ones -- allow for smoother, quicker movement as long as the player has the necessary platforming skills, and the computer terminals scattered throughout the station build enough backstory that the game never feels quite as lonely as its spiritual predecessor did.

For those that remain hungry after completing the game, there is an overwhelming amount of post-game content to challenge the player. Post-game content aside, completing the game through the first ending provides the player enough challenge, wonder and thrill that there is no reason for fans of the genre not to pick Environmental Station Alpha up at its single-digit price point, even if only on a whim.

Its not your fancy colorful artsy game you see out on the market now a days but this package will trigger your childhood memories of playing 1 of the most influential game ever made. Im not going to get into the details about a metriod game because chances are if you interested enough to read these reviews you already know the formula for this kind of game. The station is surprisingly big with tons of secrets that gracefully won't seem obvious and make you explore every nook and cranny if stumped and not sure what to do next. It may get tedious depending on how good your luck is in figuring it out but for the most part it just takes a little extra time looking for a masked block or a hidden path you just so happen to walk into. The art design of the game really puts those who like exploring weird or out of place objects revealing something useful feel at home. With that in mind the gameplay mechanics is where it gets juicy. The mobility and shooting of the hero is solid. Jumping is swift and consistent but shooting and hookshoting may take a little getting used to. Especially since the your blaster doesn't have much range for merely the entirety of the game and your hookshot(once obtained) can stick to almost any surface but swinging will need to be practiced. As you progress, each powerup fall in place and provides its usefulness. nothing revolutionary but none the less gratifying when obtained. Old school never gets old especially when enhanced with cleaner gameplay mechanics and puzzles to solve. The only downer of the game is the map. Although VERY useful (because you'll get lost often) but not very detailed. Good enough to see which direction to go but Dots and Color can only inform so much when you don't remember what the room looks like. other than that its a great Metriod replica and vast amounts of hidden secrets to uncover. So If you want a solid NES style adventure and the Metriod aesthetic environment, then the $7.99USD is a steal

reviewText:

Areas for opportunity:Navigation

This review in short: the game is great.It's a typical game trope with all the level types—water, jungle, and lava to name a few—set on a research station in space (much like Metroid Fusion). There are plenty of species you face inhabiting the biomes. Platforming while defending yourself can prove quite the challenge with only 4 directions to fire a short-ranged weapon.

Art & SoundtrackEnvironmental Station Alpha executes the retro feel excellently. The game features a darker, more neutral palette that references the original Metroid and Super Metroid. The soundtrack is along the same vein while remaining unique.

Getting LostBe prepared to get lost. There are times when your next objective is obvious, as certain events update your map with markers, but other times when they don’t. You'll often find yourself seeing places you can go, yet don't have the means to get there. There are walls you can move through to new rooms that have no visual indication, contrary to other areas that may have cracks or color variation where blocks can be broken or passed through. It becomes irritating when progression is based on luck, shooting and jumping into random walls all the time, just so you don't miss something.

ExplorationAs is the nature of exploration, you'll be doing some backtracking. But know that areas aren't always as they were the first time, be it new enemies, closed off routes from overgrowth, and activated security systems adding challenges to your original paths. In addition, there are teleporters to get around the station quickly, which makes the exploring less redundant.

WritingThere are a few moments when the script makes the dialogue and message logs feel like a poor fan-fiction. It can remove the player from the immersion at times, but mostly, it's solid and believable. The story is driven primarily by these logs, so be prepared to read.

Boss DesignBoss battles are great. Each is a unique experience in varying difficulty and techniques required to beat them. There are a number of optional and secret bosses that test your understanding of the physics of the game.

DepthThe game goes surprisingly deep with optional power ups, secret areas, an alien language, hidden rooms, easter eggs, and tons of post-game content, all of which the game doesn't spoil for the curious explorer. The game has even seen the addition of a new area since its initial release.

SummaryIf you enjoy the Metroid franchise, you'll likely enjoy Environmental Station Alpha. It's undeniably influenced by that series, but most certainly no carbon copy. This is no cheap-but-short indie game. It is similar in length to Metroid, and even deeper with its secrets. If you think you'll have Samus Aran's familiar arm cannon and powerups, then you're in for a pleasant surprise.

As of writing this review I have less than an hour of play time, but I am already in love with this game. I will come through and edit this review as needed when I finish the game, but off the bat there were so many good things that I liked.

Environmental Station Alpha was introduced to me through a Metroid community, by someone who claimed that it had a very much Metroid feel to it. It becomes very aparent that this is incredibly true. The isolation and exploration are two huge giveaways, and the boss fights just add to it. As a massive Metroid fan, and someone who plays games that try to replicate the Metroid-feel, I can say for sure that this is one of the games that manages to pull it off exceptionally well.

ESA, at least the very very early game (Pre-second boss) is a lot like the classic Metroid in that it is very unforgiving. Health is pretty sparce (as far as I know, only save stations replenish), which made each encouter much more tense because I could only afford a few hits before I was killed.

The game tells a lot through the use of color, but some parts are missing a bit of color. I found myself constantly falling in the green water (acid?) and not realizing it until my character exploded. The acid is only showing as a collection of green pixel waves at the top of the liquid. I think possibly filling in the pools with even a light, almost completely transparent green, would make them a bit more visable to the player. So far I've seen a lot of use of cool colors for the backgrounds. Dark blues, greys, purples, and blacks dominate the colors, with a bit of red accents. Most interactable machines are easy to pick out because they generally use brighter cool colors, and machines such as the save station feature a lot of contrasting red to really pop out. Walking in to an environment with a new color palette than before really adds to that exploration factor because you feel like you're finding new things, new places.

The bosses are the right amount of hard from what I found. Without doing any sort of walkthrough I could easily see myself taking no more than two tries on the bosses that I faced. You just need to take time to learn their patterns and find a way to hit them without hurting yourself.

When I first saw the store page for this game, I noticed multiple developer announcements, many regarding patches. So I came in expecting a bit of a buggy game, but not in a bad way because it seems the developers are hard at work fixing everything they can. Great job guys. I personally only had issues with enemies being stuck in vertical 'doorways' to another level, which really just made them an easy target, and I also had some framerate issues (Intel i5 4200H, GTX 860m) occasionally, but both issues were nothing to really get upset about. reviewText: There's a been a trend of late where classic genres of games have been coming back via the indie scene.  One can imagine, with the passage of time, these game genres have evolved.  To me, Environmental Station Alpha is just that.\nEnvironmental Station Alpha lives much in the spirit of Super Metroid, with a dash of Bionic Commando. My final file complete time was around 10 hours, but due to bad process management and numerous deaths/reset, I likely completed the game in around 20. If you're on the fence there's a demo, which does feature one of the more skill-based mechanics.

reviewText:
As far as Metroid clones go, Environmental Station Alpha is very faithful to the original and Super Metroid in terms of design, for better or worse, though it feels more like a mixture of Super Metroid and Fusion in terms of atmosphere. In many ways, the game does retain a distinct Metroid feel throughout, but unfortunately it falls off where those didn't with a very limited arsenal, infrequent pickups, and combat that starts to feel like a chore after a while. Traversing the station was a lot of fun, and I liked the segments where I had to explore far more than any time the game tested my combat ability, which, because of a lack of any long beam, felt like a repetitive slog through boss mechanics.

The graphics leave something wanting as well, as the environments feel sparse and retro, which works very well, but anything which animates is far too simplistic, and I found it straining to look at after a while, especially the player sprite.

A worthy sendoff to Samus this is not, but there is some fun to be had as it isn't a shallow parody of a Metroid game, merely an underdeveloped love-letter to one. I recommend only for those truly hungry for an isolating exploration platformer.

I really like Metroid and Castlevania games and I really looked forward to Environmental Station Alpha.
But sadly the game just continues to confuse and annoy me that I no longer want to complete it anymore. I quit at the part where some enemies were following you on the Y axis in the Volcano area, next to a room with fireball spitting Piranha plants.

=============

Its good aspects:
- It is aesthetically a nice game, very loyal to the 8-bit graphics I liked with NES games.
- It has a nice soundtrack and atmosphere, it really felt like a Metroid inspired game.
- The boss battles I did were fun, you may need to learn a pattern, but they were fun to play.

=============

But, its bad aspects:

- It is a difficult game, you dont have a lot of health. The enemies and the environment tend to do a lot of damage later in the game. You can crank up your HP by editing the game's config, but I think the ingame upgrades should do this.

- It is a cryptic game, I often did not know what I had to do in order to progress. At first the game helps out with messages on ingame computers, but later on I often had the feeling I was missing certain items in order to progress like a vertical boost jump. I spent a lot of time looking for a fourth energy source in the Temple area, it turned out you had to move through a wall to get to it. I had to look on a YouTube video to figure this one out, that area just looks too much like a plain wall. In Metroid, a Zoomer (enemy) would have crawled along the wall and disappeared inside the hidden part to give a hint. If it were for a secret item like the disks, it would be fine. But not in order to progress in the storyline.

- It is a hard platformer, where you really need to master the hookshot jumps to get where you need to go. Too often I get knocked off by Rinka enemies, falling stalagtites or projectiles and drop into acid or lava. It just becomes annoying after too many times. However, some people may think this is where the challenge of the game is and consider it a good point.

- It is not very rewarding, I think it would have been better if boss battles rewarded you with upgrades rather than having to search for them. Also the heat suit kind of disappointed me, I need it just to get through a few areas. The Metroid Varia suit, deducts damage done from enemies and allows you to walk in lava. Also, killing enemies become a bit of a chore, they do not drop anything usefull like health.

=============

Because of these points I do not recommend this game to other players. Im just a casual gamer however and people with more skill and patience probably will find this game enjoyable.
I really wanted to like this game inspired by Metroid, but it just became too difficult and cryptic  for me to keep up with it.

reviewText:
Fun for what it is, I suppose, but also has major flaws, leading to intense frustration.  Main game has its up points (good boss design, varied environments, fun powerups, excellent music), but also suffers from poor overall map design from a game-progression standpoint.  Typically, a well crafted, exploration-based, Metroidvania-style game will follow a logical, carefully-planned sequence--the game won't explicitly tell you where to go, but is designed to lead you to the path to progress.  This is not the case in ESA, where I often had to wonder around aimlessly (for long periods of time) to figure out where I was supposed to go next, or how to get the powerup that I could see but could not otherwise reach.

Map design aside, unless played on easy, the typical player will be unlikely to complete the normal game storyline due to the high (sometimes extreme) difficulty.  The main game storyline is a disappointment and all the possible endings are very unsatisfying -- I won't provide specific details as to avoid spoilers (though you would not be missing much, anyway). Overall, I think the game was a good effort towards its intended role of providing a nostalgic look at the classic, Metroid-style gameplay. ESA is mostly low-res Metroid. Much of the game feels like Metroid. It's atmospheric and doesn't give much in the way of guidance. Exploration is key here. I played on normal, but there is an easy mode if the difficulty is too high.

For how long the game is... it depends. The first/main ending was 7-8 hours. There's a lot of optional stuff - upgrades, bosses, collectables. reviewText:
ESa is structured a lot like the original Metroid and definitely pays homage to it. The game is very much focused around exploring a huge map with varied environments to find new power-ups that help you explore further. This is coupled with finding random HP upgrades that are often hiding behind breakable walls and discovering the lore of the area you are exploring.

Overall the game plays well. The controls are far more responsive than the game it pays homage too, which assists greatly in the epic boss fights and some incredibly difficult platforming segments. ESa makes very good use of allowing the player to traverse the environment using it's various power-ups even before the correct power-up for a certain segment is found. There were numerous times where determination and precision got me to an area I would have normally required a power-up I didn't have to get to.

Speaking of bosses, they are balls hard. You can't take very many hits, so most boss fights require the player to know all of the boss' attack patterns and how to deal with them. This is both a strength and weakness of the game. On one hand the bosses being so difficult made defeating them feel really satisfying. On the other, losing repeatedly to the same boss in it's last phase is frustrating as hell. This frustration also partly comes from having to reload from the last save point, which is only near a boss about half the time. The other half of the time you have some walking to do.

The only other gripe I had with the game was a brief segment in the middle where the game gave me no direction on where to go next. I still hadn't discovered enough power-ups to really explore the station fully on my own and I spent about 5 hours trying to figure out where the way forward was. This really messed with the pacing of the game.

Overall I quite liked the game. I'd recommend it if you are looking for a Metroid-like experience, or you like games that are old-school hard.
